verses.text: Certain men in Egypt, of angelic life and conversation, fled from the disquiet of the state and chose to live in solitude in the wilderness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:14
verses.text: There they made the sandy and barren soil bear fruit; for a fruit right sweet and fair to God was the virtue by whose law they lived.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:15
verses.text: Among many who took the lead in this mode of life was the far-famed Antonius, most excellent master in the school of mortification, who made the desert a training place of virtue for his hermits.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:16
verses.text: He after all his great and glorious labours had reached the haven where the winds of trouble blow no more, and then his followers were persecuted by the wretched and unhappy Lucius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:17
verses.text: All the leaders of those divine companies, the famous Macarius, his namesake, Isidorus, and the rest were dragged out of their caves and despatched to a certain island inhabited by impious men, and never blessed with any teacher of piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:18
verses.text: When the ship drew near to the shore of the island the demon reverenced by its inhabitants departed from the image which had been his time-old home, and filled with frenzy the daughter of the priest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:19
verses.text: She was driven in her inspired fury to the shore where the rowers were bringing the ship to land.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:20
verses.text: Making the tongue of the girl his instrument, the demon shouted out through her the words uttered at Philippi by the woman possessed with the spirit of Python, and was heard by all, both men and women, saying, "Alas for your power, ye servants of the Christ; everywhere we have been driven forth by you from town and hamlet, from hill and height, from wastes where no men dwell; in yon islet we had hoped to live out of the reach of your shafts, but our hope was vain; hither you have been sent by your persecutors, not to be harmed by them, but to drive us out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:21
verses.text: We are quitting the island, for we are being wounded by the piercing rays of your virtue".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:22
verses.text: With these words, and words like these, they dashed the damsel to the ground, and themselves all fled together.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:23
verses.text: But that divine company prayed over the girl and raised her up, and delivered her to her father made whole and in her right mind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:24
verses.text: The spectators of the miracle flung themselves at the feet of the new comers and implored to be allowed to participate in the means of salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:25
verses.text: They destroyed the idol's grove, and, illuminated by the bright rays of instruction, received the grace of holy baptism.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:26
verses.text: On these events becoming known in Alexandria all the people met together, reviling Lucius, and saying that wrath from God would fall upon them, were not that divine company of saints to be set free.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:27
verses.text: Then Lucius, apprehensive of a tumult in the city, suffered the holy hermits to go back to their dens.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:28
verses.text: Let this suffice to give a specimen of his impious iniquity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:29
verses.text: The sinful deeds he dared to do will be more clearly set forth by the letter of the admirable Peter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 18:30
verses.text: I hesitate to insert it at full length, and so will only quote some extracts from it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:2
verses.text: —Narrative of events at Alexandria in the time of Lucius the Arian, taken from a letter of Petrus, Bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:3
verses.text: Palladius governor of the province, by sect a heathen, and one who habitually prostrated himself before the idols, had frequently entertained the thought of waging war against Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:4
verses.text: After collecting the forces already enumerated he set out against the Church, as though he were pressing forward to the subjugation of a foreign foe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:5
verses.text: Then, as is well known, the most shocking deeds were done, and at the bare thought of telling the story, its recollection fills me with anguish.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:6
verses.text: I have shed floods of tears, and I should have long remained thus bitterly affected had I not assuaged my grief by divine meditation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:7
verses.text: The crowds intruded into the church called Theonas and there instead of holy words were uttered the praises of idols; there where the Holy Scriptures had been read might be heard unseemly clapping of hands with unmanly and indecent utterances; there outrages were offered to the Virgins of Christ which the tongue refuses to utter, for "it is a shame even to speak of them".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:8
verses.text: On only hearing of these wrongs one of the well disposed stopped his ears and prayed that he might rather become deaf than have to listen to their foul language.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:9
verses.text: Would that they had been content to sin in word alone, and had not surpassed the wickedness of word by deed, for insult, however bad it be, can be borne by them in whom dwells Christ's wisdom and His holy lessons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:10
verses.text: But these same villains, vessels of wrath fitted for destruction, screwed up their noses and poured out, if I may so say, as from a well-head, foul noises through their nostrils, and rent the raiment from Christ's holy virgins, whose conversation gave an exact likeness of saints; they dragged them in triumph, naked as when they were born, through all the town; they made indecent sport of them at their pleasure; their deeds were barbarous and cruel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:11
verses.text: Did any one in pity interfere and urge to mercy he was dismissed with wounds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:12
verses.text: Ah! woe is me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:13
verses.text: Many a virgin underwent brutal violation; many a maid beaten on the head, with clubs lay dumb, and even their bodies were not allowed to be given up for burial, and their grief-stricken parents cannot find their corpses to this day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:14
verses.text: But why recount woes which seem small when compared with greater? Why linger over these and not hurry on to events more urgent? When you hear them I know that you will wonder and will stand with us long dumb, amazed at the kindness of the Lord in not bringing all things utterly to an end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:15
verses.text: At the very altar the impious perpetrated what, as it is written, neither happened nor was heard of in the days of our fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:16
verses.text: A boy who had forsworn his sex and would pass for a girl, with eyes, as it is written, smeared with antimony, and face reddened with rouge like their idols, in woman's dress, was set up to dance and wave his hands about and whirl round as though he had been at the front of some disreputable stage, on the holy altar itself where we call on the coming of the Holy Ghost, while the by-standers laughed aloud and rudely raised unseemly shouts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:17
verses.text: But as this seemed to them really rather decorous than improper, they went on to proceedings which they reckoned in accordance with their indecency; they picked out a man who was very famous for utter baseness, made him strip off at once all his clothes and all his shame, and set him up as naked as he was born on the throne of the church, and dubbed him a vile advocate against Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:18
verses.text: Then for divine words he uttered shameless wickedness, for awful doctrines wanton lewdness, for piety impiety, for continence fornication, adultery, foul lust, theft; teaching that gluttony and drunkenness as well as all the rest were good for man's life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:19
verses.text: In this state of things when even I had withdrawn from the church—for how could I remain where troops were coming in—where a mob was bribed to violence—where all were striving for gain—where mobs of heathen were making mighty promises?—forth, forsooth, is sent a successor in my place.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:20
verses.text: It was one named Lucius, who had bought the bishopric as he might some dignity of this world, eager to maintain the bad character and conduct of a wolf.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:21
verses.text: No synod of orthodox bishops had chosen him; no vote of genuine clergy; no laity had demanded him; as the laws of the church enjoin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:22
verses.text: Lucius could not make his entrance into the city without parade, and so he was appropriately escorted not by bishops, not by presbyters, not by deacons, not by multitudes of the laity; no monks preceded him chanting psalms from the Scriptures; but there was Euzoius, once a deacon of our city of Alexandria, and long since degraded along with Arius in the great and holy synod of Nicaea, and more recently raised to rule and ravage the see of Antioch, and there, too, was Magnus the treasurer, notorious for every kind of impiety, leading a vast body of troops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:23
verses.text: In the reign of Julian this Magnus had burnt the church at Berytus, the famous city of Phoenicia; and, in the reign of Jovian of blessed memory, after barely escaping decapitation by numerous appeals to the imperial compassion, had been compelled to build it up again at his own expense.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:24
verses.text: Now I invoke your zeal to rise in our vindication.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:25
verses.text: From what I write you ought to be able to calculate the character and extent of the wrongs committed against the Church of God by the starting up of this Lucius to oppose us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:26
verses.text: Often rejected by your piety and by the orthodox bishops of every region, he seized on a city which had just and righteous cause to regard and treat him as a foe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:27
verses.text: For he does not merely say like the blasphemous fool in the psalms "Christ is not true God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:28
verses.text: But, corrupt himself, he corrupted others, rejoicing in the blasphemies uttered continually against the Saviour by them who worshipped the creature instead of the Creator.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:29
verses.text: The scoundrel's opinions being quite on a par with those of a heathen, why should he not venture to worship a new-made God, for these were the phrases with which he was publicly greeted "Welcome, bishop, because thou deniest the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:30
verses.text: Serapis loves thee and has brought thee to us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:31
verses.text: So they named their native idol.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:32
verses.text: Then without an interval of delay the afore-named Magnus, inseparable associate in the villainy of Lucius, cruel body-guard, savage lieutenant, collected together all the multitudes committed to his care, and arrested presbyters and deacons to the number of nineteen, some of whom were eighty years of age, on the charge of being concerned in some foul violation of Roman law.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:33
verses.text: He constituted a public tribunal, and, in ignorance of the laws of Christians in defence of virtue, endeavoured to compel them to give up the faith of their fathers which had been handed down from the apostles through the fathers to us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:34
verses.text: He even went so far as to maintain that this would be gratifying to the most merciful and clement Valens Augustus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:35
verses.text: "Wretched man" he shouted "accept, accept the doctrine of the Arians; God will pardon you even though you worship with a true worship, if you do this not of your own accord but because you are compelled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:36
verses.text: There is always a defence for irresponsible compulsion, while free action is responsible and much followed by accusation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:37
verses.text: Consider well these arguments; come willingly; away with all delay; subscribe the doctrine of Arius preached now by Lucius," (so he introduced him by name) "being well assured that if you obey you will have wealth and honour from your prince, while if you refuse you will be punished by chains, rack, torture, scourge and cruel torments; you will be deprived of your property and possessions; you will be driven into exile and condemned to dwell in savage regions".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:38
verses.text: Thus this noble character mixed intimidation with deceit and so endeavoured to persuade and compel the people to apostatise from true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:39
verses.text: They however knew full well how true it is that the pain of treachery to right religion is sharper than any torment; they refused to lower their virtue and noble spirit to his trickery and threats, and were thus constrained to answer him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:40
verses.text: "Cease, cease trying to frighten us with these words, utter no more vain words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:41
verses.text: We worship no God of late arrival or of new invention.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:42
verses.text: Foam at us if you will in the vain tempest of your fury and dash yourselves against us like a furious wind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:43
verses.text: We abide by the doctrines of true religion even unto death; we have never regarded God as impotent, or as unwise, or untrue, as at one time a Father and at another not a Father, as this impious Arian teaches, making the Son a being of time and transitory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:44
verses.text: For if, as the Ariomaniacs say, the Son is a creature, not being naturally of one substance with the Father, the Father too will be reduced to non-existence by the nonexistence of the Son, not being as they assert at one period a Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:45
verses.text: But if He is ever a Father, his offspring being truly of Him, and not by derivation, for God is impassible, how is not he mad and foolish who says of the Son through whom all things came by grace into existence, "there was a time when he was not".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:46
verses.text: These men have truly become fatherless by falling away from our fathers throughout the world who assembled at Nicaea, and anathematized the false doctrine of Arius, now defended by this later champion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:47
verses.text: They laid down that the Son was not as you are now compelling us to say, of a different substance from the Father, but of one and the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:48
verses.text: This their pious intelligence clearly perceived, and so from an adequate collation of divine terms they owned Him to be consubstantial.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:49
verses.text: Advancing these and other similar arguments, they were imprisoned for many days in the hope that they might be induced to fall away from their right mind, but the rather, like the noblest of the athletes in a Stadium, they crushed all fear, and from time to time as it were anointing themselves with the thought of the bold deeds done by their fathers, through the help of holy thoughts maintained a nobler constancy in piety, and treated the rack as a training place for virtue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:50
verses.text: While they were thus struggling, and had become, as writes the blessed Paul, a spectacle to angels and to men, the whole city ran up to gaze at Christ's athletes, vanquishing by stout endurance the scourges of the judge who was torturing them, winning by patience trophies against impiety, and exhibiting triumphs against Arians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:51
verses.text: So their savage enemy thought that by threats and torments he could subdue and deliver them to the enemies of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:52
verses.text: Thus therefore the savage and inhuman tyrant evilly entreated them by inflicting on them the tortures that his cruel ingenuity devised, while all the people stood wailing and shewing their sorrow in various ways.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:53
verses.text: Then he once more mustered his troops, who were disciplined in disorder, and summoned the martyrs to trial, or as it might rather be called, to a foregone condemnation, by the seaport, while after their fashion hired cries were raised against them by the idolaters and the Jews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:54
verses.text: On their refusal to yield to the manifest heresy of the Ariomaniacs they were sentenced, while all the people stood in tears before the tribunal, to be deported from Alexandria to the Phoenician Heliopolis, a place where none of the inhabitants, who are all given over to idols, can endure so much as to hear the name of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:55
verses.text: After giving them the order to embark, Magnus stationed himself at the port, for he had delivered his sentence against them in the neighbourhood of the public baths.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:56
verses.text: He showed them his sword unsheathed, thinking that he could thus strike terror into men who had again and again smitten hostile demons to the ground with their two-edged blade.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:57
verses.text: So he bade them put out to sea, though they had got no provisions on board, and were starting without one single comfort for their exile.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:58
verses.text: Strange and almost incredible to relate, the sea was all afoam; grieved, I think, and unwilling, if I may so say, to receive the good men upon its surface, and so have part or lot in an unrighteous sentence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:59
verses.text: Now even to the ignorant was made manifest the savage purpose of the judge and it may truly be said "at this, the heavens stood astonished".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:60
verses.text: The whole city groaned, and is lamenting to this day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:61
verses.text: Some men beating on their breast with one hand after another raised a mighty noise; others lifted up at once their hands and eyes to heaven in testimony of the wrong inflicted on them, and so saying in all but words, "Hear, O heavens, and give ear, O earth," what unlawful deeds are being done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:62
verses.text: Now all was weeping and wailing; singing and sighing sounded through all the town, and from every eye flowed a river of tears which threatened to overwhelm the very sea with its tide.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:63
verses.text: There was the aforesaid Magnus on the port ordering the rowers to hoist the sails, and up went a mingled cry of maids and matrons, old men and young, all sobbing and lamenting together, and the noise of the multitude overwhelmed the roar raised by the waves on the foaming sea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:64
verses.text: So the martyrs sailed off for Heliopolis, where every man is given over to superstition, where flourish the devil's ways of pleasure, and where the situation of the city, surrounded on all sides by mountains that approach the sky, is fitted for the terrifying lairs of wild beasts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:65
verses.text: All the friends they left behind now alike in public in the middle of the town and each in private apart groaned and uttered words of grief, and were even forbidden to weep, at the order of Palladius, prefect of the city, who happened himself to be a man quite given over to superstition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:66
verses.text: Many of the mourners were first arrested and thrown into prison, and then scourged, torn with carding combs, tortured, and, champions as they were of the church in their holy enthusiasm, were despatched to the mines of Phennesus and Proconnesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:67
verses.text: Most of them were monks, devoted to a life of ascetic solitude, and were about twenty-three in number.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:68
verses.text: Not long afterwards the deacon who had been sent by our beloved Damasus, bishop of Rome, to bring us letters of consolation and communion, was led publicly through the town by executioners, with his hands tied behind his back like some notorious criminal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:69
verses.text: After sharing the tortures inflicted on murderers, he was terribly scourged with stones and bits of lead about his very neck.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:70
verses.text: He went on board ship to sail, like the rest, with the mark of the sacred cross upon his brow; with none to aid and none to tempt him he was despatched to the copper mines of Phennesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:71
verses.text: During the tortures inflicted by the magistrate on the tender bodies of little boys, some have been left lying on the spot deprived of holy rites of burial, though parents and brothers and kinsfolk, and indeed the whole city, begged that this one consolation might be given them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:72
verses.text: But alas for the inhumanity of the judge, if indeed he can be called judge who only condemns! They who had contended nobly for the true religion were assigned a worse fate than a murderer's, their bodies lying, as they did, unburied.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:73
verses.text: The glorious champions were thrown to be devoured by beasts and birds of prey.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:74
verses.text: Those who were anxious for conscience' sake to express sympathy with the parents were punished by decapitation, as though they had broken some law.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:75
verses.text: What Roman law, nay what foreign sentiment, ever inflicted punishment for the expression of sympathy with parents? What instance is there of the perpetration of so illegal a deed by any one of the ancients? The male children of the Hebrews were indeed once ordered to be slain by Pharaoh, but his edict was suggested by envy and by fear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:76
verses.text: How far greater the inhumanity of our day than of his.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:77
verses.text: How preferable, if there be a choice in unrighteousness, their wrongs to ours.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:78
verses.text: How much better; if what is illegal can be called good or bad, though in truth iniquity is always iniquity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:79
verses.text: I am writing what is incredible, inhuman, awful, savage, barbarous, pitiless, cruel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:80
verses.text: But in all this the votaries of the Arian madness pranced, as it were, with proud exultation, while the whole city was lamenting; for, as it is written in Exodus, "there was not a house in which there was not one dead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:81
verses.text: The men whose appetite for iniquity was never satisfied planned new agitation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:82
verses.text: Ever wreaking their evil will in evil deeds, they darted the peculiar venom of their iniquity at the bishops of the province, using the aforesaid treasurer Magnus as the instrument of their unrighteousness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:83
verses.text: Some they delivered to the Senate, some they trapped at their good pleasure, leaving no stone unturned in their anxiety to hunt in all from every quarter to impiety, going about in all directions, and like the devil, the proper father of heresy, they sought whom they might devour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:84
verses.text: In all, after many fruitless efforts, they drove into exile to Dio-Caesarea, a city inhabited by Jews, murderers of the Lord, eleven of the bishops of Egypt, all of them men who from childhood to old age had lived an ascetic life in the desert, had subdued their inclinations to pleasure by reason and by discipline, had fearlessly preached the true faith of piety, had imbibed the pious doctrines, had again and again won victory against demons, were ever putting the adversary out of countenance by their virtue, and publicly posting the Arian heresy by wisest argument.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:85
verses.text: Yet like Hell, not satisfied with the death of their brethren, fools and madmen as they were, eager to win a reputation by their evil deeds, they tried to leave memorials in all the world of their own cruelty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:86
verses.text: For lo now they roused the imperial attention against certain clerics of the catholic church who were living at Antioch, together with some excellent monks who came forward to testify against their evil deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:87
verses.text: They got these men banished to Neocaesarea in Pontus, where they were soon deprived of life in consequence of the sterility of the country.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 19:88
verses.text: Such tragedies were enacted at this period, fit indeed to be consigned to silence and oblivion, but given a place in history for the condemnation of the men who wag their tongues against the Only begotten, and infected as they were with the raving madness of blasphemy, strive not only to aim their shafts at the Master of the universe, but further waged a truceless war against His faithful servants.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:2
verses.text: —Of Mavia, Queen of the Saracens, and the ordinationof Moses the monk.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:3
verses.text: At this time the Ishmaelites were devastating the country in the neighbourhood of the Roman frontier.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:4
verses.text: They were led by Mavia, a princess who regarded not the sex which nature had given her, and displayed the spirit and courage of a man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:5
verses.text: After many engagements she made a truce, and, on receiving the light of divine knowledge, begged that to the dignity of high priest of her tribe might be advanced one, Moses by name, who dwelt on the confines of Egypt and Palestine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:6
verses.text: This request Valens granted, and ordered the holy man to be conveyed to Alexandria, and there, as the most convenient place in the neighbourhood, to receive episcopal grace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:7
verses.text: When he had arrived and saw Lucius endeavouring to lay hands on him—"God forbid" said he "that I should be ordained by thine hand: the grace of the Spirit visits us not at thy calling".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:8
verses.text: "Whence," said Lucius, "are you led to conjecture this?" He rejoined "I am not speaking of conjecture but of clear knowledge; for thou fightest against the apostolic decrees, and speakest words against them, and for thy blasphemous utterances thy lawless deeds are a match.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:9
verses.text: For what impious man has not on thy account mocked the meetings of the Church? What excellent man has not been exiled? What barbarous savagery is not thrown into the shade by thy daily deeds?" So the brave man said, and the murderer heard him and desired to slay him, but was afraid of kindling once again the war which had come to an end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:10
verses.text: Wherefore he ordered other bishops to be produced whom Moses had requested.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:11
verses.text: After receiving the episcopal grace of the right worthy faith Moses returned to the people who had asked for him, and by his apostolic teaching and miracles led them in the way that leads to truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 20:12
verses.text: These then were the deeds done by Lucius in Alexandria under the dispensation of the providence of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI  At Constantinople the Arians filled a boat with pious presbyters and drove her without ballast out to sea, putting some of their own men on another craft with orders to set the presbyters boat on fire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 21:2
verses.text: So, fighting at the same time against both sea and flames, at last they were delivered to the deep, and won the martyrs crown.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 21:3
verses.text: At Antioch Valens spent a considerable time, and gave complete license to all who, under cover of the Christian name, pagans, Jews and the rest, preached doctrines contrary to those of the gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 21:4
verses.text: The slaves of this error even went so far as to perform pagan rites, and thus the deceitful fire which, after Julian, had been quenched by Jovian, was now rekindled by permission of Valens.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 21:5
verses.text: The rites of Jews, of Dionysus, and of Demeter were now no longer performed in a corner, as they would be in a pious reign, but by revellers running wild in the forum.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 21:6
verses.text: Valens was a foe to none but them that held the apostolic doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 21:7
verses.text: First he drove them from their churches, the illustrious Jovian having given them also the new built church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 21:8
verses.text: And when they assembled close up to the mountain cliff to honour their Master in hymns, and enjoy the word of God, putting up with all the assaults of the weather, now of rain, now of snow and cold, and now of violent heat, they were not even suffered this poor protection, and troops were sent to scatter them far and wide.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:2
verses.text: —How Flavianus and Diodorus gathered the church of the orthodox in Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:3
verses.text: Now Flavianus and Diodorus, like break-waters, broke the force of the advancing waves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:4
verses.text: Meletius their shepherd had been constrained to sojourn far away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:5
verses.text: But these looked after the flock, opposing their own courage and cunning to the wolves, and bestowing due care upon the sheep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:6
verses.text: Now that they were driven away from under the cliff they fed their flocks by the banks of the neighbouring river.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:7
verses.text: They could not brook, like the captives at Babylon, to hang their harps upon the willows, but they continued to hymn their maker and benefactor in all places of his dominion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:8
verses.text: But not even in this spot was the meeting of the pious pastors of them that blessed the Lord suffered by the foe to be assembled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:9
verses.text: So again this pair of excellent shepherds gathered their sheep in the soldiers training ground and there tried to show them their spiritual food in secret.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:10
verses.text: Diodorus, in his wisdom and courage, like a clear and mighty river, watered his own and drowned the blasphemies of his opponents, thinking nothing of the splendour of his birth, and gladly undergoing the sufferings of the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:11
verses.text: The excellent Flavianus, who was also of the highest rank, thought piety the only nobility, and, like some trainer for the games, anointed the great Diodorus as though he had been an athlete for five contests.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:12
verses.text: At that time he did not himself preach at the services of the church, but furnished an abundant supply of arguments and scriptural thoughts to preachers, who were thus able to aim their shafts at the blasphemy of Arius, while he as it were handed them the arrows of his intelligence from a quiver.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:13
verses.text: Discoursing alike at home and abroad he easily rent asunder the heretics nets and showed their defences to be mere spiders webs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:14
verses.text: He was aided in these contests by that Aphraates whose life I have written in my Religious History, and who, preferring the welfare of the sheep to his own rest, abandoned his cell of discipline and retirement, and undertook the hard toil of a shepherd.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 22:15
verses.text: Having written on these matters in another work I deem it now superfluous to recount the wealth of virtue which he amassed, but one specimen of his good deeds I will proceed now to relate, as specially appropriate to this history.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:2
verses.text: —Of the holy monk Aphraates.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:3
verses.text: On the north of the river Orontes lies the palace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:4
verses.text: On the South a vast two storied portico is built on the city wall with lofty towers on either side.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:5
verses.text: Between the palace and the river lies a public way open to passengers from the town, through the gate in this quarter, and leading to the country in the suburbs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:6
verses.text: The godly Aphraates was once passing along this thoroughfare on his way to the soldiers' training ground, in order to perform the duty of serving his flock.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:7
verses.text: The emperor happened to be looking down from a gallery in the palace, and saw him going by wearing a cloak of undressed goat's skin, and walking rapidly, though of advanced age.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:8
verses.text: On its being remarked that this was Aphraates to whom all the town was then attached, the emperor cried out "Where are you going? Tell us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:9
verses.text: Readily and cleverly he answered "To pray for your empire".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:10
verses.text: "You had better stop at home" said the emperor "and pray alone like a monk".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:11
verses.text: "Yes," said the divine man, "so I was bound to do and so I always did till now, as long as the Saviour's sheep were at peace; but now that they are grievously disturbed and in great peril of being caught by beasts, I needs must leave no means untried to save the nurslings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:12
verses.text: For tell me, sir, had I been a girl sitting in my chamber, and looking after the house, and had seen a flash of flame fall and my father's house on fire, what ought I to do? Tell me; sit within and never mind the house being on fire, and wait for the flame to approach? or bid my bower good bye and run up and down and get water and try to quench the flame? Of course you will say the latter, for so a quick and spirited girl would do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:13
verses.text: And that is what I am doing now, sir.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:14
verses.text: You have set fire to our Father's house and we are running about in the endeavour to put it out".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:15
verses.text: So said Aphraates, and the emperor threatened him and said no more.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:16
verses.text: One of the grooms of the imperial bedchamber, who threatened the godly man somewhat more violently, met with the following fate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:17
verses.text: He was entrusted with the charge of the bath, and immediately after this conversation he came down to get it ready for the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:18
verses.text: On entering he lost his wits, stepped into the boiling water before it was mixed with the cold, and so met his end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:19
verses.text: The emperor sat waiting for him to announce that the bath was ready for him to enter, and after a considerable time had gone by he sent other officers to report the cause of the delay.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:20
verses.text: After they had gone in and looked all about the room they discovered the chamberlain slain by the heat, and lying dead in the boiling water.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:21
verses.text: On this becoming known to the emperor they perceived the force of the prayers of Aphraates.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 23:22
verses.text: Nevertheless they did not depart from the impious doctrines but hardened their heart like Pharaoh, and the infatuated emperor, though made aware of the miracle of the holy man, persisted in his mad rage against piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 24:2
verses.text: —Of the holy monk Julianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 24:3
verses.text: At this time too the celebrated Julianus, whom I have already mentioned, was forced to leave the desert and come to Antioch, for when the foster children of lies, the facile framers of calumny, I mean of course the Arians, were maintaining that this great man was of their faction, those lights of the truth Flavianus, Diodorus, and Aphraates sent Acacius, an athlete of virtue who afterwards very wisely ruled the church at Beroea, to the famous Julianus with the entreaty that he would take pity on so many thousands of men, and at the same time convict the enemy of lies and confirm the proclamation of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 24:4
verses.text: The miracles worked by Julianus on his way to and from Antioch and in that vast city itself are described in my Religious History, which is easily accessible to all who wish to become acquainted with them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 24:5
verses.text: But I am sure that no one who has enquired into human nature will doubt that he attracted all the population of the city to our assembly, for the extraordinary is generally sure to draw all men after it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 24:6
verses.text: The fact of his having wrought great marvels is attested even by the enemies of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 24:7
verses.text: Before this time in the reign of Constantius the great Antonius had acted in the same way in Alexandria, for he abandoned the desert and went up and down that city, telling all men that Athanasius was the preacher of the true doctrine and that the Arian faction were enemies of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 24:8
verses.text: So those godly men knew how to adapt themselves to each particular opportunity, when to remain inactive, and at rest, and when to leave the deserts for towns.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:2
verses.text: —Of what other monks were distinguished at this period.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:3
verses.text: There were also other men at this period who emitted the bright rays of the philosophy of solitary life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:4
verses.text: In the Chalcidian desert Avitus, Marcianus and Abraames, and more besides whom I cannot easily enumerate, strove in their bodies of sense to live a life superior to sense.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:5
verses.text: In the district of Apamea, Agapetus, Simeon, Paulus and others reaped the fruits of the highest wisdom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:6
verses.text: In the district of the Zeugmatenses were Publius and Paulus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:7
verses.text: In the Cyrestian the famous Acepsemas had been shut up in a cell for sixty years without being either seen or spoken to.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:8
verses.text: The admirable Zeumatius, though bereft of sight, used to go about confirming the sheep, and fighting with the wolves; so they burnt his cell, but the right faithful general Trajanus got another built for him, and paid him besides other attentions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:9
verses.text: In the neighbourhood of Antioch, Marianus, Eusebius, Ammianus, Palladius, Simeon, Abraames, and others, preserved the divine image unimpaired; but of all these the lives have been recorded by us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 25:10
verses.text: But the mountain which is in the neighbourhood of the great city was decked like a meadow, for in it shone Petrus, the Galatian, his namesake the Egyptian, Romanus Severus, Zeno, Moses, and Malchus, and many others of whom the world is ignorant, but who are known to God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:2
verses.text: —Of Didymus of Alexandria and Ephraim the Syrian.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:3
verses.text: At that period at Edessa flourished the admirable Ephraim, and at Alexandria Didymus, both writers against the doctrines that are at variance with the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:4
verses.text: Ephraim, employing the Syrian language, shed beams of spiritual grace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:5
verses.text: Totally untainted as he was by heathen education he was able to expose the niceties of heathen error, and lay bare the weakness of all heretical artifices.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:6
verses.text: Harmonius the son of Bardesanes had once composed certain songs and by mixing sweetness of melody with his impiety beguiled the hearers, and led them to their destruction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:7
verses.text: Ephraim adopted the music of the songs, but set them to piety, and so gave the hearers at once great delight and a healing medicine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:8
verses.text: These songs are still used to enliven the festivals of our victorious martyrs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:9
verses.text: Didymus, however, who from a child had been deprived of the sense of sight, had been educated in poetry, rhetoric, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, the logic of Aristotle, and the eloquence of Plato.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:10
verses.text: Instruction in all these subjects he received by the sense of hearing alone,—not indeed as conveying the truth, but as likely to be weapons for the truth against falsehood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:11
verses.text: Of holy scriptures he learnt not only the sound but the sense.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 26:12
verses.text: So among livers of ascetic lives and students of virtue, these men at that time were conspicuous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 27:2
verses.text: —Of what bishops were at this time distinguished in Asia and Pontus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 27:3
verses.text: Among the bishops were the two Gregorii, the one of Nazianzus and the other of Nyssa, the latter the brother and the former the friend and fellow worker of the great Basilius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 27:4
verses.text: These were foremost champions of piety in Cappadocia; and in front rank with them was Peter, born of the same parents with Basilius and Gregorius, who though not having received like them a foreign education, like them lived a life of brilliant distinction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 27:5
verses.text: In Pisidia Optimus, in Lycaonia Amphilochius, fought in the front rank on behalf of their fathers' faith, and repelled the enemies' assaults.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 27:6
verses.text: In the West Damasus, Bishop of Rome, and Ambrosius, entrusted with the government of Milan, smote those who attacked them from afar.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 27:7
verses.text: In conjunction with these, bishops forced to dwell in remote regions, confirmed their friends and undid their foes by writings—thus pilots able to cope with the greatness of the storm were granted by the governor of the universe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 27:8
verses.text: Against the violence of the foe He set in battle array the virtue of His captains, and provided means meet to ward off the troubles of these difficult times, and not only were the churches granted this kind of protection by their loving Lord, but deemed worthy of yet another kind of guidance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 28:2
verses.text: —Of the letter written by Valens to the great Valentinianus about the war, and how he replied.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 28:3
verses.text: The Lord roused the Goths to war, and drew on to the Bosphorus him who knew only how to fight against the pious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 28:4
verses.text: Then for the first time the vain man became aware of his own weakness, and sent to his brother to ask for troops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 28:5
verses.text: But Valentinian replied that it were impious to help one fighting against God, and right rather to check his rashness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 28:6
verses.text: By this the unhappy man was filled with yet greater infatuation, yet he did not withdraw from his rash undertaking, and persisted in ranging himself against the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 29:2
verses.text: —Of the piety of Count Terentius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 29:3
verses.text: Terentius, an excellent general, distinguished for his piety, had set up trophies of victory and returned from Armenia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 29:4
verses.text: On being ordered by Valens to choose a boon, he mentioned one which it was becoming in a man nurtured in piety to choose, for he asked not gold nor yet silver, not land, not dignity, not a house, but that one church might be granted to them that were risking their all for the Apostolic doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 29:5
verses.text: Valens received the petition, but on becoming acquainted with its contents he tore it up in a rage, and bade Terentius beg some other boon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 29:6
verses.text: The count, however, picked up the pieces of his petition, and said, "I have my reward, sir, and I will not ask another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 29:7
verses.text: The Judge of all things is Judge of my intention".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 30:2
verses.text: —Of the bold utterance of Trajanus the general.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 30:3
verses.text: After Valens had crossed the Bosphorus and come into Thrace he first spent a considerable time at Constantinople, in alarm as to the issue of the war.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 30:4
verses.text: He had sent Trajanus in command of troops against the barbarians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 30:5
verses.text: When the general came back beaten, the emperor reviled him sadly, and charged him with infirmity and cowardice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 30:6
verses.text: Boldly, as became a brave man, Trajanus replied: "I have not been beaten, sir, it is thou who hast abandoned the victory by fighting against God and transferring His support to the barbarians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 30:7
verses.text: Attacked by thee He is taking their side, for victory is on God's side and comes to them whom God leads.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 30:8
verses.text: Dost thou not know," he went on, "whom thou hast expelled from their churches and to whose government these churches have been delivered by thee?" Arintheus and Victor, generals like Trajanus, confirmed the truth of what he said, and implored the emperor not to be angered by reproaches which were founded upon fact.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 31:2
verses.text: —Of Isaacthe monk of Constantinople and Bretanio the Scythian Bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 31:3
verses.text: It is related that Isaac, who lived as a solitary at Constantinople, when he saw Valens marching out with his troops, cried aloud, "Whither goest thou, O emperor? To fight against God, instead of having Him as thy ally? 'Tis God himself who has roused the barbarians against thee, because thou hast stirred many tongues to blasphemy against Him and hast driven His worshippers from their sacred abodes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 31:4
verses.text: Cease then thy campaigning and stop the war.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 31:5
verses.text: Give back to the flocks their excellent shepherds and thou shalt win victory without trouble, but if thou fightest without so doing thou shalt learn by experience how hard it is to kick against the pricks.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 31:6
verses.text: Thou shalt never come back and shalt destroy thy army".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 31:7
verses.text: Then in a passion the emperor rejoined, "I shall come back; and I will kill thee, and so exact punishment for thy lying prophecy".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 31:8
verses.text: But Isaac undismayed by the threat exclaimed, "If what I say be proved false, kill me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 31:9
verses.text: Bretanio, a man distinguished by various virtues, and entrusted with the episcopal government of all the cities of Scythia, fired his soul with enthusiasm, and protested against the corruption of doctrines, and the emperor's lawless attacks upon the saints, crying in the words of the godly David, "I spoke of thy testimonies also before Kings and was not ashamed".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 32:2
verses.text: —Of the expedition of Valens against the Goths and how he paid the penalty of his impiety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 32:3
verses.text: Valens, however, spurned these excellent counsellors, and sent out his troops to join battle while he himself sat waiting in a hamlet for the victory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 32:4
verses.text: His troops could not stand against the barbarians' charge, turned tail and were slain one after another as they fled, the Romans fleeing at full speed and the barbarians chasing them with all their might.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 32:5
verses.text: When Valens heard of the defeat he strove to conceal himself in the village where he lay, but when the barbarians came up they set the place on fire and together with it burnt the enemy of piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 32:6
verses.text: Thus in this present life Valens paid the penalty of his errors.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:2
verses.text: —How the Goths became tainted by the Arian error.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:3
verses.text: To those ignorant of the circumstances it may be worth while to explain how the Goths got the Arian plague.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:4
verses.text: After they had crossed the Danube, and made peace with Valens, the infamous Eudoxius, who was on the spot, suggested to the emperor to persuade the Goths to accept communion with him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:5
verses.text: They had indeed long since received the rays of divine knowledge and had been nurtured in the apostolic doctrines, "but now," said Eudoxius, "community of opinion will make the peace all the firmer".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:6
verses.text: Valens approved of this counsel and proposed to the Gothic chieftains an agreement in doctrine, but they replied that they would not consent to forsake the teaching of their fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:7
verses.text: At the period in question their Bishop Ulphilas was implicitly obeyed by them and they received his words as laws which none might break.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:8
verses.text: Partly by the fascination of his eloquence and partly by the bribes with which he baited his proposals Eudoxius succeeded in inducing him to persuade the barbarians to embrace communion with the emperor, so Ulphilas won them over on the plea that the quarrel between the different parties was really one of personal rivalry and involved no difference in doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:9
verses.text: The result is that up to this day the Goths assert that the Father is greater than the Son, but they refuse to describe the Son as a creature, although they are in communion with those who do so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book IV 33:10
verses.text: Yet they cannot be said to have altogether abandoned their Father's teaching, since Ulphilas in his efforts to persuade them to join communion with Eudoxius and Valens denied that there was any difference in doctrine and that the difference had arisen from mere empty strife.
